page.title: 09MONK'S PARK QUARRY,CORSHAM
page.content: The underground workings at Corsham started following the Box Tunnel excavation in the early nineteenth century. Mining is important to Corsham because of the oolitic limestone found in this area. There is now just one surviving mine,Monks Park,Corsham. It is believed there are still vast quantities of the stone underground. A lot of the stone produced in the Monks Park mine is used on the outside walls of buildings. At the old stone yard in Potley, they receive all types of Bath Stone from Monks Park. They are given the stone in big blocks and then it is cut into slabs with a frigbob. Even the dust is sold for cement. At Monks Park there are 33 acres of tunnels, although half of the underground area is now occupied by the Navy.
